title: How to Identify Lumps on Your Cat

steps.title: See a vet as soon as possible about new lumps.
steps.content: See a vet as soon as possible about new lumps. In general, you should have any lumps that last more than a week or two checked out by your vet. However, it’s worth noting that small lumps that are not growing, oozing anything, or bothering your cat are unlikely to be dangerous. [1] X Research source If a lump appears suddenly and grows noticeably, take your cat to the vet at your earliest convenience.

steps.title: Monitor seemingly innocuous lumps.
steps.content: Monitor seemingly innocuous lumps. Some lumps will be entirely harmless. For instance, hard tissue that forms at the site of an injury or after a surgery is most likely simply scar tissue. However, if a lump ever seems to bother your cat or seems infected, have it looked at right away. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Allow your vet to do tests.
steps.content: Allow your vet to do tests. Your vet will likely be able to determine whether a particular lump is fluid-filled, such as an abscess, or is solid, such as a tumor or cyst. However, they will not be able to determine whether a tumor is harmless or dangerous without doing tests. They will likely need to use a needle or scalpel to remove a small amount of tissue from the lump and test it in a lab. [3] X Research source Note that their initial tests will be quick, easy, and safe. They can likely be completed while your cat is awake, and will cause little to no pain.

steps.title: Agree to a biopsy.
steps.content: Agree to a biopsy. Your vet will recommend a biopsy if they are not able to determine the cause of a lump through initial tests. Your cat will be anesthetized so that part or all of the lump can be removed. This is worthwhile, as it allows your vet to get a definitive diagnosis on the cause of the lump. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Determine whether the cat has been fighting.
steps.content: Determine whether the cat has been fighting. Abscesses are a common type of lump that usually form a few days after a fight with another cat or dog. They are rather large and filled with fluid. If you notice your cat seems feverish or unwell and has a lump with a scab in the middle, it is likely an abscess. [5] X Research source Abscesses are bacterial infections. While they are usually not too dangerous, it’s best to have a vet look at them. They can drain the fluid and prescribe your cat antibiotics to rid their body of infection.

steps.title: Assess whether an ear lump is a hematoma.
steps.content: Assess whether an ear lump is a hematoma. Blood can collect beneath the skin at the site of a minor injury. This will form a swollen, fluid-filled lump called a hematoma. Hematomas are common on cats that shake their head vigorously and damage the capillaries between the cartilage and skin of their ear. [6] X Research source Haematomas need to be evaluated by a veterinarian. There is usually an underlying cause of a hematoma, which requires treatment. For example, it may be the result of ear mites or an infection that caused your cat to damage their ear.

steps.title: Have cysts removed.
steps.content: Have cysts removed. Some cysts may be caused by blocked hair follicles or oil ducts. If a lump appears suddenly but doesn’t change, and has a hair growing from its center, it may be a cyst. They can be left alone if they do not repeatedly get infected or bother your cat. [7] X Research source If you're unsure, the safest option is having a vet check on a cyst and determine whether it should be removed.

steps.title: Consider a potential food allergy.
steps.content: Consider a potential food allergy. If you have recently changed the type of food you feed your cat and notice lumps on their head and neck, the lumps are likely evidence of an allergic reaction. Discontinue feeding them that food and see if the lumps subside. [8] X Research source Lumps of this sort will be small, pale, and filled with fluid. While the lumps themselves are not dangerous, your cat may hurt itself by scratching.

steps.title: Rule out flea bites.
steps.content: Rule out flea bites . If lumps are small, reddish, and slightly pointed, they are likely flea bites. They will usually be accompanied by scratching, and maybe hair loss. Talk to your vet about how to get rid of the fleas, and watch out for wounds on your cat’s skin where they are constantly licking and scratching. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Check your cat for tumors regularly.
steps.content: Check your cat for tumors regularly. Check for lumps on your cat every month, and whenever their behavior changes. If a lump turns out to be a tumor, the sooner it is addressed, the better. Start by placing both of your hands on top of your cat’s head and petting them around their ears and beneath their neck. Then check their front legs, beneath the shoulders, and down their back and belly. Finally, feel their hips and back legs. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Call your vet or set up an appointment to have any new lumps inspected.

steps.title: Recognize a benign tumor.
steps.content: Recognize a benign tumor. Tumors that are benign, meaning that they are not cancerous, will generally grow very slowly. You may notice one when it is still small, and may never even notice a change in size. Lumps from benign tumors will be rounded and firm. You may be able to move them around beneath the skin. The skin itself will not appear unhealthy. [11] X Trustworthy Source American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Leading organization dedicated to the prevention of animal cruelty Go to source Benign tumors are generally not a risk to your cat, but it’s worth having a vet check it out. Some tumors that seem benign can still be cancerous. Your vet will likely recommend removal of a tumor on a cat’s face or legs, even if it’s benign. Otherwise, they will likely recommend leaving a benign tumor alone.

steps.title: Have any growing lump checked out.
steps.content: Have any growing lump checked out. Malignant, cancerous tumors pose a risk to your cat and should be addressed immediately. Fortunately, they are also relatively easy to identify. Foremost, malignant tumors will seemingly appear suddenly, be surprisingly large, and will grow noticeably quickly. They may be an odd shape, and the skin above them may appear discolored or otherwise unhealthy. [12] X Research source
